Mike Clark wrote:
> 
> I like how you think, Todd.  :-)
> 
> I don't know the history behind the design decision to use static 
> methods in Assert, but I'd love to know.

I think they intended to do what NUnit did  (Assert.IsFalse()), didn't 
like it, pushed the methods into a superclass of TestCase, then forgot 
to make them instance-level. Damn.

> For lack of a better way to log each assertion, I can only offer one 
> suggestion:  You have the source.  It wouldn't bother me to roll a 
> custom JUnit and distribute it on a project, as long as it didn't 
> fundamentally change how folks expect to use it.

Scott Stirling came to the same conclusion in his excellent chapter on 
reporting JUnit results. I couldn't find anything better, either.
